segment.tokens: A favourite terrier was in the habit of accompanying his master , who was a clergyman , to church , where he was so perfectly quiet , that few persons knew of his presence
his master was a to church , where he was so perfectly quiet
where he was so perfectly
that few persons knew of his presence
On one occasion he went to a funeral
when the procession left the church
accompanied his master to the side of the grave , where he mingled with the attendants
where he mingled with the attendants
The parties remained for some little time looking at the coffin
looking at the coffin
after it was lowered
the clergyman slipped away unobserved even by his dog
as he sat at dinner with his friends
An hour after his sexton requested to speak with him
He was admitted into the room
when he said
it was to close the grave
that he did not know what to do
asked the gentleman " "
Because Sir your terrier stands there
your terrier flies so fiercely at us
whenever we attempt to throw a spade full in
that we dare not go on
One of the house servants was sent to the churchyard
there saw the dog in a perfect fury
defending the grave
she refused to come to his call so
by main force he removed her
he carried her to the drawing-room
There the moment she saw her master
her transport of joy equalled her former fury
it is supposed
that not seeing
her master go away
that missing him
she fancied
he was in the grave
she thus strove to protect him from injury
The same dog a companion equally faithful sagacious attached themselves to their master 's horse
whenever they could
went out with it
He rode out on it to dinner the two dogs with him
the two dogs with him went contentedly into the stable with their friend
He ordered his horse when it time to go away
was
as it was a long
coming to the door
inquiries were made about the delay
which the groom appeared
the groom said
he dared not
take the horse of the stable
out
for one of the clergyman 's dogs was on its back , and the other by its side flying at every person who came near the animal
every person came near the animal
The owner comprehended the mystery
going to the stable himself
The owner brought forth the steed
the groom was a
the dogs dared not
trust him with their master 's property
known to Professor Owen
A terrier was taught to play at hide
A terrier seek with his master , who summoned him , by saying " Let us have a game , " upon which the dog immediately hid his eyes between his paws , in the most honourable manner
his master summoned him saying " in the most honourable manner
Let us
" have a game
which the dog immediately hid his eyes between his paws
when the gentleman had placed a sixpence a piece of cake in a most improbable place
he started up
he invariably found it
His powers were equalled
what was called a Fox-terrier
named Fop
a Fox-terrier would hide his eyes
a Fox-terrier suffer those at play with him to conceal themselves
before he looked up
If his playfellow hid himself behind a window curtain
Fop would for a certain time carefully pass that curtain
Fop look behind all the others , behind doors , etc.
when he thought
he had looked long enough
Fop seize the concealing curtain
drag it aside in triumph
The drollest thing however was to see he fancy
him take his turn of hiding
he would get under a chair fancy
that he was not seen
of course those at play with him pretended not to see him
it was most to witness his agitation
as they passed
When he was ever after
he had been cured some hom≈ìopathic globules
if anything were the with him
ever after he would stand near the medicine box
he hold his mouth open
belonging to a linen-draper in Swindon
directly the shop was opened in the morning
A black tan terrier was in the habit of going to the post-office with his master
the letter bag was put into his mouth
he carried it home
One morning he took it into his head to precede his master
he go alone
The post-master seeing him felt so certain
his owner was at the door
that he delivered the bag to him
the bag to him he ran home
while his master was seeking him
From that time it became his regular duty to fetch the letters daily
Sir Walter Scott tells us of the remarkable comprehension of human language evinced by his Bull-dog terrier , called Camp
evinced his Bull-dog terrier
called Camp
He understood so many words
that Sir Walter felt convinced
an intercourse with dumb animals might be
Camp once bit the baker
the baker Sir Walter beat him
Sir Walter at the same time explained the enormity of the offence

after which to the last moment of his life he never heard the least allusion to the story , in whatever voice or tone it might be mentioned , without getting up and retiring into the darkest corner of the room , with great appearance of distress
to the story , in whatever voice or tone it might be mentioned , without getting up and retiring into the darkest corner of the room , with great appearance of distress
if it were said
that the baker had been well paid
that the baker was not hurt after all
Camp came forward
Then capered
barked
rejoiced
When he was towards the end of his life to attend his master in his rides
he watched for his return
used to tell him Sir Walter
the servant was coming down the hill
through the moor Camp never mistook him either
although he did not use any gesture either
went out at the front to ascend the hills at the back to get at the moor side
